raw_text:
Smartphones suffer Skulls attack
 
 Owners of some Nokia smartphones are being warned to watch out for malicious wallpaper.
 
 Those downloading the software could find all the icons on their 7610 phone swapped for images of skulls. When installed the malicious program also locks many of the 7610's functions making it hard to use and harder to repair. The program is only the latest in a series of viruses produced to attack mobile phones.
 
 The file, nicknamed Skulls, is thought to have surfaced on shareware sites where people can pick up free add-ons, such as wallpaper, games and ringtones, for their phones Symbian said that it was not sure if the damage Skulls does was intentional or simply a result of bad programming. Soon after being discovered the file is thought to have been removed from the sites that were unwittingly harbouring it. The program is masquerading as software that creates new background images and themes for the main screen of the 7610 phone. The Skulls program is labelled as a file called: 7610.extended.theme.manager.zip.
 
 Once installed the program replaces all the icons on the main page with skulls and replaces all the working applications, such as contacts, calendar, notebook etc with non-working versions so the phone becomes almost useless. The only thing the phone can do is make and take calls. A statement by Symbian played down the significance of the malicious program and said few people would fall victim to it as users have to go through several steps to install it, one of which includes ignoring a security warning. Symbian said that the spread of the Skulls program was likely to be limited as the program cannot travel from one phone to another by itself. Despite this Finnish anti-virus lab F-Secure said it had sporadic reports of 7610 owners being caught out by it. The firm has produced guidance for users caught out to help them remove the program and get their phone working again. The Skulls program is thought to have been written by a malicious hacker using the alias Tee-222. Symbian phones produced by Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima and Fujitsu are unaffected by the Skulls program.
llama3.2:1b: Smartphones with Nokia models 7610 may be vulnerable to malware known as "Skulls". The virus, created by hacker Tee-222, replaces icons on the home screen with skulls and disables working applications, making the phone unusable for calls only. Users are warned not to install it due to security risks and can remove it using guidance from F-Secure.
llama3.2:3b: Nokia smartphone owners warned about malicious wallpaper that replaces icons with skulls and locks functions making phone unusable. The software, called "Skulls," was found on shareware sites and has been removed from those sites but may still spread through user actions. Symbian says few people will be affected due to security measures, but F-Secure reports sporadic cases of phone users being caught out by the program.
gemma2:2b: A malicious program called "Skulls" is infecting some Nokia 7610 smartphones. It replaces icons with skulls, disables applications, and makes the phone unusable for most tasks except calling. The program likely spread through shareware sites due to its disguise as a theme manager.  While the program's spread is limited as it cannot jump from one phone to another, reports of infected users exist.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Nokia smartphones are being warned about a malicious wallpaper called Skulls which could cause problems with some of their phone functions such as making and taking calls. The file is called 7610.extended.theme.manager.zip and was found on shareware sites where people can download free add-ons for phones like Symbian. Initially, the program was thought to be harmless but it was later discovered that it could cause problems with Nokia's phones. Users are advised to look out for this malicious wallpaper and not install any new software without being sure that they're downloading from a reputable source.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Owners of some Nokia 7610 smartphones may be vulnerable to a Skulls attack that replaces icons with skulls and disables many functions, rendering the device almost useless. The malicious program, nicknamed Skulls, is found on Symbian sites offering add-ons such as wallpapers and themes but not all users are aware they can download it from there. Users have to manually install the dangerous file and ignore a security warning to complete the process. Although some 7610 owners were reportedly caught by the program, Finnish anti-virus lab F-Secure did receive reports of affected devices. The damage appears to be limited as Symbian phones made by other manufacturers are not vulnerable.
qwen2.5:3b: Smartphones with Nokia 7610 models face a threat from a malware dubbed Skulls that swaps icons on their main screen with skulls and locks essential functions like contacts and calendar. The malicious software is believed to masquerade as a background image creator for Symbian phones. Once installed, it disables useful applications, leaving users only able to make and receive calls. Users need to take several steps to install the program, including ignoring security warnings. While few people fall victim due to these precautions, some Nokia 7610 owners have fallen prey to Skulls. The malware is believed to be work of a malicious hacker using alias Tee-222. Affected phones include those from Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and Fujitsu; Symbian phones by other manufacturers remain unaffected. F-Secure advises users how to remove the program.
opencoder:1.5b: Smartphones suffer Skulls attack. Owners of some Nokia smartphones are being warned to watch out for malicious wallpaper. Those downloading the software could find all the icons on their 76-102 phone swapped for images of skulls. When installed the malicious program also locks many of the 76-10's functions making it hard to use and harder to repair. The program is only the latest in a series of viruses produced to attack mobile phones. The file, nicknamed Skulls, is thought to have surfaced on shareware sites where people can pick up free add-ons, such as wallpaper, games and ringtones, for their phones Symbian said that it was not sure if the damage Skulls does was intentional or simply a result of bad programming. Soon after being discovered the file is thought to have been removed from the sites that were unwittingly harbouring it. The program is masquerading as software that creates new background images and themes for the main screen of the 76-10 phone. The Skulls program is labelled as a file called: 76-102.extended.theme.manager.zip. Once installed, the program replaces all the icons on the main page with skulls and replaces all the working applications, such as contacts, calendar, notebook etc with non-working versions so the phone becomes almost useless. A statement by Symbian played down the significance of the malicious program and said few people would fall victim to it as users have to go through several steps to install it, one of which includes ignoring a security warning. Despite this Finnish anti-virus lab F-Secure has sporadic reports of 76-10 owners being caught out by it. The firm has produced guidance for users caught out to help them remove the program and get their phone working again. The Skulls program is thought to have been written by a malicious hacker using the alias Tee-222. Symbian phones produced by Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima and Fujitsu are unaffected by the Skulls program.
smollm:1.7b: The Smartphones suffer Skulls attack refers to the malware that has affected some Nokia smartphones, causing damage to their operating system and potentially leading to other problems. The malicious software is thought to have been designed to exploit vulnerabilities in the phones' operating systems or to steal sensitive information from users.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text about Nokia's software attack affecting their 7610 smartphones. First, I'll read through the provided text carefully to identify the main points.

The text starts by mentioning that some Nokia smartphones are being warned for a "skull" attack due to malicious wallpaperware. The attackers have swapped all icons with skull images and are also blocking many functions. They make the phone hard to use and harder to repair because of this issue.

Next, it says that the file is called Skulls and is available on shareware sites. It was unclear whether the damage was intentional or accidental. I should note both possibilities but keep it concise.

Symbian confirms that the Skulls program is 7610.extended.theme.manager.zip. Installing it replaces icons with skulls, making the phone unusable for calls only. The statement by Symbian downplays the impact and suggests users ignore warnings to install it.

The text then mentions that few people were affected because installing it requires several steps. Finnish firm F-Secure reported some 7610 owners caught by Skulls, but they're made from Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and Fujitsu. The attackers used the alias Tee-222.

Finally, Symbian explains that the attack is likely not widespread because the program doesn't spread on its own. They provided guidelines for users to remove the program and fix their phones.

I need to condense all these points into a concise summary without any explanations or formatting.
</think>

Some Nokia 7610 smartphones are being warned due to malicious wallpaperware that replaces icons with skull images, blocking functions and making the phone hard to use. The file is called Skulls and was found on shareware sites but its impact isn't fully clear. Symbian stated few users were affected because installing it required steps beyond warnings, though attackers used Tee-222 and targeted brands like Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and Fujitsu. F-Secure reported some affected users, but the issue is likely local to those using the software.
tinyllama:1.1b: Unless users ignore security warnings, smartphone users can be targeted by a new type of malicious software known as "Skulls," which swaps icon images on the main screen for skulls and replaces working applications with non-functioning versions. The program, dubbed as an add-on or extension to a phone's system, is not meant to be downloaded from third-party sources and has been discovered by Symbian, a Finnish anti-virus lab, but has not yet been removed due to its limited potential for spreading and causing harm. Users who do not want the Skulls program installed on their phone should ignore any warnings presented by the software installer, which may prompt them to allow it or close the app once they have downloaded and installed it. While most Finnish users are not affected by the malicious program, a warning is still necessary for those who use smartphones produced by Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and FujiTsu.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The Nokia phone owners are being warned that their smartphones might be infected with a malicious wallpaper called "Skulls". 

The virus attacks by swapping the existing icons on the screen for ones of skulls, making it difficult to use and hard to repair. The software is created using Nokia's shareware model, where people can download free add-ons for their phones. If users don't pay close attention and don't remove the malicious wallpaper before installing, they might end up with a damaged phone that is almost useless for communication.

The Finnish anti-virus lab F-Secure has warned users to be careful about clicking on links or downloading files from shareware sites, as many of these contain malicious software. The Skulls program is thought to have originated with a hacker using the alias Tee-222 and using Symbian operating systems.
phi:2.7b: Some Nokia smartphone owners are at risk of having their  761 phone infected with malicious wallpaper software that changes all the icons to skulls and locks many functions, making it unusable. The virus is part of a series of malware targeting mobile phones and can be downloaded from shareware sites. Symbian, the operating system used by Nokia's smartphones, says the damage is not intentional but may have been due to bad programming. The program disguises itself as software for creating new themes and images and requires several steps to install. Most users will not fall victim to it, but F-Secure, a Finnish anti-virus lab, has reported sporadic cases of it catching out some Nokia users. To remove the virus, users are advised by Symbian to go back to their phone's menu and select "delete". They may also need to reset their network settings.
orca-mini:3b: Nokia smartphones suffer from a virus called Skulls that can replace icons with skulls and replace working applications with non-working versions, making them almost useless. The program requires users to go through several steps to install it and is masquerading as software that creates new background images and themes for the main screen of the 7610 phone. The Skulls program is labelled as a file called 7610.extended.theme.manager.zip and can only be installed on certain Nokia smartphones produced by Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and Fujitsu. F-Secure, a Finnish anti-virus lab, has reported sporadic cases of users being caught out by the program. The program cannot travel from one phone to another by itself and is written by a malicious hacker using the alias Tee-222. Symbian phones produced by those manufacturers are unaffected by the Skulls program.
hermes3:3b:
Nokia 7610 smartphones vulnerable to 'Skulls' malware
* Malicious wallpaper installed through shareware sites
* Locks phone functions and makes it hard to repair
* Not intentionally malicious but due to bad programming
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A new mobile virus targeting Nokia 7100 smartphones has been discovered, replacing icons and locking functions to make the device unusable. The "Skulls" malware appears as a malicious wallpaper on shareware websites before spreading to other phones through social connections or via an infected email. Symbian, the operating system manufacturer, downplayed the severity of the Skulls program but acknowledged sporadic reports of affected smartphones. Owners of the Nokia 7100 are advised to keep their devices up-to-date and avoid downloading non-recommended software from shareware sites.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Owners of Nokia 7610 smartphones are warned about a malicious program called Skulls, which disguises itself as wallpaper software but replaces all icons with skulls and disables key functions, rendering the phone nearly useless. The program, found on shareware sites, does not spread automatically and requires users to bypass security warnings to install it. While its damage may be unintentional, reports indicate some users have been affected. Finnish security firm F-Secure has provided removal guidance. Other Symbian-based phones from Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and Fujitsu are unaffected.
stablelm2:1.6b: Nokia smartphone owners are warned about a malicious wallpaper called "Skulls" that could replace icons with images of skulls and lock many functions on their device. The software is said to have been created on shareware sites as a free add-on, masquerading as software for creating themes and background images for the phones. Once installed, it replaces all working applications and mostly useless phone functions, making it challenging to repair. Symbian downplays its impact, but F-Secure reports occasional instances of infected users. The Skulls program is likely limited in its spread due to its inability to travel between devices independently; however, some Finnish anti-virus labs have caught the program. The program was created by a malicious hacker using the alias Tee-Barcode. Symbian phones from Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, and Fujitsu are unaffected by this malware.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Smartphone users of Nokia 7610 models should be cautious about a malicious wallpaper file called "Skulls," or "7610.extended.theme.manager.zip." This program, found on shareware sites, replaces icons with skulls and disables essential functions, rendering the phone nearly useless for anything other than making and receiving calls. The damage could be intentional or a result of poor programming. Despite Symbian's downplay of its significance, users must follow specific installation steps to install it, including ignoring a security warning. Anti-virus firm F-Secure has reported sporadic cases of this issue, offering guidance for affected users to recover their phones. The Skulls program is linked to a hacker named Tee-222 and does not affect Symbian phones from manufacturers like Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima, or Fujitsu.
reference: Symbian said that the spread of the Skulls program was likely to be limited as the program cannot travel from one phone to another by itself.Symbian phones produced by Sony Ericsson, Motorola, BenQ, Arima and Fujitsu are unaffected by the Skulls program.The Skulls program is thought to have been written by a malicious hacker using the alias Tee-222.The Skulls program is labelled as a file called: 7610.extended.theme.manager.zip.The firm has produced guidance for users caught out to help them remove the program and get their phone working again.The file, nicknamed Skulls, is thought to have surfaced on shareware sites where people can pick up free add-ons, such as wallpaper, games and ringtones, for their phones Symbian said that it was not sure if the damage Skulls does was intentional or simply a result of bad programming.The program is masquerading as software that creates new background images and themes for the main screen of the 7610 phone.
